bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, November 6, 1952

div1.p: Hench thinks that Camp Lazear will be called “Parque Finlay,” which he regrets. He is very distressed after seeing photographs which show that Building No. 1 is being repaired extensively rather than enclosed and preserved. He feels the building will be a replica and not a restoration. He mentions the recent death of Cooke.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, November 6, 1952
div1.opener:
November 6, 1952
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I have been hopping all over the country, so busy. As I wrote you,
Doctor Nogueira informed me that your name is to be on one of the bronze
tablets now being erected at Camp Lazear. The Camp is to be dedicated on
December 3. I have not yet heard of the name it will bear but I suspect
“Parque Finlay,”which I greatly regret. Nogueira writes me that you and
others will shortly receive an official invitation.

I have just received a letter from Doctor Nogueira asking if you will send
him a photograph. He does not say whether he wants it for publicity con-
nected with the dedication or to frame and hang in the little house. I am
writing him today asking him about this and will ask him to write you directly
but since time passes, I thought you had better get a photograph ready for
him. You will remember his address is Dr. Pedro Nogueira, Marti 219,
Marianao, Havana, Cuba.

Had you heard that Doctor Cooke died a couple of weeks ago? I do indeed
hope that you are feeling better. You have had a very rough time but I was
glad to know from your last letter that you seem to be improving now so
definitely.

I have been considerably distressed by another thing. Doctor Nogueira and
I have frequently talked about trying to preserve, as intact as possible,
the original shell of Building No. 1. I had hoped that a new outer shell
would be built around the original building. About a month ago, without
prior consultation or discussion, he merely wrote me that they were already
making extensive repairs to the building, tearing out part of the old wood.
I cabled him and wrote him at once expressing the hope that they could pre-
serve as much of the original wood as possible and asked him to save for me
(to use later for souvenirs) as much of the old wood walls as possible. He
assured me that he would, but photographs from him which arrived yesterday
show that they removed practically all of the walls which makes me believe
that they will end up with a replica rather than a restoration. This
distresses me greatly but perhaps it was unavoidable unless they were pre-
pared to take special care and do a special job.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
